5. Datatypes

5.1. teidata.certainty

teidata.certaintyÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a degree of certainty.
Moduletei
Used by
teidata.probCertElement:
  • purpose/@degree
Content model
<content>
Â <valListÂ type="closed">
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="high"/>
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="medium"/>
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="low"/>
Â Â <valItemÂ ident="unknown"/>
Â </valList>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.certainty = "high" | "medium" | "low" | "unknown"
Note

Certainty may be expressed by one of the predefined symbolic values high, medium, or low. The value unknown should be used in cases where the encoder does not wish to assert an opinion about the matter.

5.2. teidata.count

teidata.countÂ defines the range of attribute values used for a non-negative integer value used as a count.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • handDesc/@hands
  • refState/@length
  • tagUsage/@occurs
  • tagUsage/@withId
  • zone/@rotate
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="nonNegativeInteger"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.count = xsd:nonNegativeInteger
Note

Any positive integer value or zero is permitted

5.3. teidata.duration.iso

teidata.duration.isoÂ defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using ISO 8601 standard formats
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.duration.iso = token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }
Example
<timeÂ dur-iso="PT0,75H">three-quarters of an hour</time>
Example
<dateÂ dur-iso="P1,5D">a day and a half</date>
Example
<dateÂ dur-iso="P14D">a fortnight</date>
Example
<timeÂ dur-iso="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the last, which may have a decimal component (using either . or , as the decimal point; the latter is preferred). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first âtimeâ number-letter pair.

For complete details, see ISO 8601 Data elements and interchange formats â Information interchange â Representation of dates and times.

5.4. teidata.duration.w3c

teidata.duration.w3cÂ defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using W3C datatypes.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="duration"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.duration.w3c = xsd:duration
Example
<timeÂ dur="PT45M">forty-five minutes</time>
Example
<dateÂ dur="P1DT12H">a day and a half</date>
Example
<dateÂ dur="P7D">a week</date>
Example
<timeÂ dur="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the S number, which may have a decimal component (using . as the decimal point). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first âtimeâ number-letter pair.

For complete details, see the W3C specification.

5.5. teidata.enumerated

teidata.enumeratedÂ defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • availability/@status
  • channel/@mode
  • constitution/@type
  • correction/@status
  • correction/@method
  • correspAction/@type
  • derivation/@type
  • domain/@type
  • factuality/@type
  • fw/@type
  • geoDecl/@datum
  • hyphenation/@eol
  • idno/@type
  • interaction/@type
  • interaction/@active
  • interaction/@passive
  • list/@type
  • normalization/@method
  • num/@type
  • person/@role
  • person/@age
  • preparedness/@type
  • punctuation/@marks
  • punctuation/@placement
  • purpose/@type
  • quotation/@marks
  • rendition/@scope
  • space/@dim
  • surface/@attachment
  • title/@type
  • title/@level
  • unclear/@reason
  • unclear/@agent
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.word"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.enumerated = teidata.word
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single âwordâ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

Typically, the list of documented possibilities will be provided (or exemplified) by a value list in the associated attribute specification, expressed with a <valList> element.

5.6. teidata.language

teidata.languageÂ defines the range of attribute values used to identify a particular combination of human language and writing system. [6.1. Language Identification]
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • language/@ident
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="language"/>
Â Â <valList>
Â Â Â <valItemÂ ident=""/>
Â Â </valList>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.language = xsd:language | ( "" )
Note

The values for this attribute are language âtagsâ as defined in BCP 47. Currently BCP 47 comprises RFC 5646 and RFC 4647; over time, other IETF documents may succeed these as the best current practice.

A âlanguage tagâ, per BCP 47, is assembled from a sequence of components or subtags separated by the hyphen character (-, U+002D). The tag is made of the following subtags, in the following order. Every subtag except the first is optional. If present, each occurs only once, except the fourth and fifth components (variant and extension), which are repeatable.

language
The IANA-registered code for the language. This is almost always the same as the ISO 639 2-letter language code if there is one. The list of available registered language subtags can be found at http://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry. It is recommended that this code be written in lower case.
script
The ISO 15924 code for the script. These codes consist of 4 letters, and it is recommended they be written with an initial capital, the other three letters in lower case. The canonical list of codes is maintained by the Unicode Consortium, and is available at http://unicode.org/iso15924/iso15924-codes.html. The IETF recommends this code be omitted unless it is necessary to make a distinction you need.
region
Either an ISO 3166 country code or a UN M.49 region code that is registered with IANA (not all such codes are registered, e.g. UN codes for economic groupings or codes for countries for which there is already an ISO 3166 2-letter code are not registered). The former consist of 2 letters, and it is recommended they be written in upper case; the list of codes can be searched or browsed at https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#search/code/. The latter consist of 3 digits; the list of codes can be found at http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm.
variant
An IANA-registered variation. These codes are used to indicate additional, well-recognized variations that define a language or its dialects that are not covered by other available subtags.
extension
An extension has the format of a single letter followed by a hyphen followed by additional subtags. These exist to allow for future extension to BCP 47, but as of this writing no such extensions are in use.
private use
An extension that uses the initial subtag of the single letter x (i.e., starts with x-) has no meaning except as negotiated among the parties involved. These should be used with great care, since they interfere with the interoperability that use of RFC 4646 is intended to promote. In order for a document that makes use of these subtags to be TEI-conformant, a corresponding <language> element must be present in the TEI header.

There are two exceptions to the above format. First, there are language tags in the IANA registry that do not match the above syntax, but are present because they have been âgrandfatheredâ from previous specifications.

Second, an entire language tag can consist of only a private use subtag. These tags start with x-, and do not need to follow any further rules established by the IETF and endorsed by these Guidelines. Like all language tags that make use of private use subtags, the language in question must be documented in a corresponding <language> element in the TEI header.

Examples include

sn
Shona
zh-TW
Taiwanese
zh-Hant-HK
Chinese written in traditional script as used in Hong Kong
en-SL
English as spoken in Sierra Leone
pl
Polish
es-MX
Spanish as spoken in Mexico
es-419
Spanish as spoken in Latin America

The W3C Internationalization Activity has published a useful introduction to BCP 47, Language tags in HTML and XML.

5.7. teidata.name

teidata.nameÂ defines the range of attribute values expressed as an XML Name.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • application/@ident
  • tagUsage/@gi
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="Name"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.name = xsd:Name
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which follows the rules defining a legal XML name (see http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#dt-name): for example they cannot include whitespace or begin with digits.

5.8. teidata.namespace

teidata.namespaceÂ defines the range of attribute values used to indicate XML namespaces as defined by the W3C Namespaces in XML Technical Recommendation.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • namespace/@name
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="anyURI"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.namespace = xsd:anyURI
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax

5.9. teidata.numeric

teidata.numericÂ defines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • num/@value
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="double"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â Â restriction="(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="decimal"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.numeric =
   xsd:double | token { pattern = "(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)" } | xsd:decimal
Note

Any numeric value, represented as a decimal number, in floating point format, or as a ratio.

To represent a floating point number, expressed in scientific notation, âE notationâ, a variant of âexponential notationâ, may be used. In this format, the value is expressed as two numbers separated by the letter E. The first number, the significand (sometimes called the mantissa) is given in decimal format, while the second is an integer. The value is obtained by multiplying the mantissa by 10 the number of times indicated by the integer. Thus the value represented in decimal notation as 1000.0 might be represented in scientific notation as 10E3.

A value expressed as a ratio is represented by two integer values separated by a solidus (/) character. Thus, the value represented in decimal notation as 0.5 might be represented as a ratio by the string 1/2.

5.10. teidata.outputMeasurement

teidata.outputMeasurementÂ defines a range of values for use in specifying the size of an object that is intended for display.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="[\-+]?\d+(\.\d+)?(%|cm|mm|in|pt|pc|px|em|ex|gd|rem|vw|vh|vm)"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.outputMeasurement =
   token
   {
      pattern = "[\-+]?\d+(\.\d+)?(%|cm|mm|in|pt|pc|px|em|ex|gd|rem|vw|vh|vm)"
   }
Example
<figure> Â <head>The TEI Logo</head> Â <figDesc>Stylized yellow angle brackets with the letters <mentioned>TEI</mentioned> in Â Â  between and <mentioned>text encoding initiative</mentioned> underneath, all on a white Â Â  background.</figDesc> Â <graphicÂ height="600px"Â width="600px" Â Â url="http://www.tei-c.org/logos/TEI-600.jpg"/> </figure>
Note

These values map directly onto the values used by XSL-FO and CSS. For definitions of the units see those specifications; at the time of this writing the most complete list is in the CSS3 working draft.

5.11. teidata.pattern

teidata.patternÂ defines attribute values which are expressed as a regular expression.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.pattern = token
Note
A regular expression, often called a pattern, is an expression that describes a set of strings. They are usually used to give a concise description of a set, without having to list all elements. For example, the set containing the three strings Handel, HÃ¤ndel, and Haendel can be described by the pattern H(Ã¤|ae?)ndel (or alternatively, it is said that the pattern H(Ã¤|ae?)ndel matches each of the three strings)
Wikipedia

This TEI datatype is mapped to the XSD token datatype, and may therefore contain any string of characters. However, it is recommended that the value used conform to the particular flavour of regular expression syntax supported by XSD Schema.

5.12. teidata.point

teidata.pointÂ defines the data type used to express a point in cartesian space.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • path/@points
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="(\-?[0-9]+\.?[0-9]*,\-?[0-9]+\.?[0-9]*)"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.point = token { pattern = "(\-?[0-9]+\.?[0-9]*,\-?[0-9]+\.?[0-9]*)" }

 It is considered poor practice to end a number with a decimal point; as of 2019-02-25 TEI will consider this @points attribute of  invalid
Example
<facsimile> Â <surfaceÂ ulx="0"Â uly="0"Â lrx="400"Â lry="280"> Â Â <zoneÂ points="220,100 300,210 170,250 123,234"> Â Â Â <graphicÂ url="handwriting.png "/> Â Â </zone> Â </surface> </facsimile>
Note

A point is defined by two numeric values, which should be expressed as decimal numbers.

Currently, this datatype permits either of the two numeric values to end in a decimal point. This practice is deprecated, and as of 2019-02-25 this datatype will no longer permit a number to end in a decimal point. E.g., both 0.0,84.2 and 0,84 are allowed, but 0.,84. will not be.

5.13. teidata.pointer

teidata.pointerÂ defines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • catRef/@scheme
  • change/@target
  • classCode/@scheme
  • handShift/@new
  • keywords/@scheme
  • metamark/@target
  • note/@targetEnd
  • redo/@target
  • space/@resp
  • undo/@target
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="anyURI"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.pointer = xsd:anyURI
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax. Note that the values themselves are encoded using RFC 3987 Internationalized Resource Identifiers (IRIs) mapping to URIs. For example, https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/% is encoded as https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/%25 while http://ÙÙÙØ¹.ÙØ²Ø§Ø±Ø©-Ø§ÙØ§ØªØµØ§ÙØ§Øª.ÙØµØ±/ is encoded as http://xn--4gbrim.xn----rmckbbajlc6dj7bxne2c.xn--wgbh1c/

5.14. teidata.prefix

teidata.prefixÂ defines a range of values that may function as a URI scheme name.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • prefixDef/@ident
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="[a-z][a-z0-9\+\.\-]*"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.prefix = token { pattern = "[a-z][a-z0-9\+\.\-]*" }
Note

This datatype is used to constrain a string of characters to one that can be used as a URI scheme name according to RFC 3986, section 3.1. Thus only the 26 lowercase letters aâz, the 10 digits 0â9, the plus sign, the period, and the hyphen are permitted, and the value must start with a letter.

5.15. teidata.probCert

teidata.probCertÂ defines a range of attribute values which can be expressed either as a numeric probability or as a coded certainty value.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.probability"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.certainty"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.probCert = teidata.probability | teidata.certainty

5.16. teidata.probability

teidata.probabilityÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a probability.
Moduletei
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="double"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.probability = xsd:double
Note

Probability is expressed as a real number between 0 and 1; 0 representing certainly false and 1 representing certainly true.

5.17. teidata.replacement

teidata.replacementÂ defines attribute values which contain a replacement template.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <textNode/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.replacement = text

5.18. teidata.sex

teidata.sexÂ defines the range of attribute values used to identify human or animal sex.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • person/@sex
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ key="teidata.word"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.sex = teidata.word
Note

Values for attributes using this datatype may be locally defined by a project, or may refer to an external standard, such as vCard's sex property http://microformats.org/wiki/gender-formats (in which M indicates male, F female, O other, N none or not applicable, U unknown), or the often used ISO 5218:2004 Representation of Human Sexes http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/c036266_ISO_IEC_5218_2004(E_F).zip (in which 0 indicates unknown; 1 male; 2 female; and 9 not applicable, although the ISO standard is widely considered inadequate); cf. CETH's Recommendations for Inclusive Data Collection of Trans People http://transhealth.ucsf.edu/trans?page=lib-data-collection.

5.19. teidata.temporal.iso

teidata.temporal.isoÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the international standard Data elements and interchange formats â Information interchange â Representation of dates and times.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="date"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gYear"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gMonth"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gDay"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gYearMonth"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gMonthDay"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="time"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="dateTime"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â Â restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.temporal.iso =
   xsd:date
 |Â xsd:gYear
 |Â xsd:gMonth
 |Â xsd:gDay
 |Â xsd:gYearMonth
 |Â xsd:gMonthDay
 |Â xsd:time
 |Â xsd:dateTime
 |Â token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }
Note

If it is likely that the value used is to be compared with another, then a time zone indicator should always be included, and only the dateTime representation should be used.

For all representations for which ISO 8601 describes both a basic and an extended format, these Guidelines recommend use of the extended format.

While ISO 8601 permits the use of both 00:00 and 24:00 to represent midnight, these Guidelines strongly recommend against the use of 24:00.

5.20. teidata.temporal.w3c

teidata.temporal.w3cÂ defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition specification.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="date"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gYear"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gMonth"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gDay"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gYearMonth"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="gMonthDay"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="time"/>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="dateTime"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.temporal.w3c =
   xsd:date
 |Â xsd:gYear
 |Â xsd:gMonth
 |Â xsd:gDay
 |Â xsd:gYearMonth
 |Â xsd:gMonthDay
 |Â xsd:time
 |Â xsd:dateTime
Note

If it is likely that the value used is to be compared with another, then a time zone indicator should always be included, and only the dateTime representation should be used.

5.21. teidata.text

teidata.textÂ defines the range of attribute values used to express some kind of identifying string as a single sequence of unicode characters possibly including whitespace.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • refState/@delim
  • rendition/@selector
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="string"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.text = string
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single âtokenâ in which whitespace and other punctuation characters are permitted.

5.22. teidata.truthValue

teidata.truthValueÂ defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • listChange/@ordered
  • note/@anchored
  • surface/@flipping
  • tagsDecl/@partial
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="boolean"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.truthValue = xsd:boolean
Note

The possible values of this datatype are 1 or true, or 0 or false.

This datatype applies only for cases where uncertainty is inappropriate; if the attribute concerned may have a value other than true or false, e.g. unknown, or inapplicable, it should have the extended version of this datatype: data.xTruthValue.

5.23. teidata.version

teidata.versionÂ defines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • TEI/@version
  • teiCorpus/@version
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.version = token { pattern = "[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}" }
Note

The value of this attribute follows the pattern specified by the Unicode consortium for its version number (http://unicode.org/versions/). A version number contains digits and fullstop characters only. The first number supplied identifies the major version number. A second and third number, for minor and sub-minor version numbers, may also be supplied.

5.24. teidata.versionNumber

teidata.versionNumberÂ defines the range of attribute values used for version numbers.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • application/@version
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.versionNumber =
   token { pattern = "[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}" }

5.25. teidata.word

teidata.wordÂ defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single word or token.
Moduletei
Used by
teidata.enumerated teidata.sexElement:
  • metamark/@function
  • secl/@reason
  • supplied/@reason
  • surplus/@reason
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="token"
Â Â restriction="(\p{L}|\p{N}|\p{P}|\p{S})+"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.word = token { pattern = "(\p{L}|\p{N}|\p{P}|\p{S})+" }
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single âwordâ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

5.26. teidata.xTruthValue

teidata.xTruthValueÂ (extended truth value) defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value which may be unknown.
Moduletei
Used by
Content model
<content>
Â <alternate>
Â Â <dataRefÂ name="boolean"/>
Â Â <valList>
Â Â Â <valItemÂ ident="unknown"/>
Â Â Â <valItemÂ ident="inapplicable"/>
Â Â </valList>
Â </alternate>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.xTruthValue = xsd:boolean | ( "unknown" | "inapplicable" )
Note

In cases where where uncertainty is inappropriate, use the datatype data.TruthValue.

5.27. teidata.xmlName

teidata.xmlNameÂ defines attribute values which contain an XML name.
Moduletei
Used by
Element:
  • schemaRef/@key
Content model
<content>
Â <dataRefÂ name="NCName"/>
</content>
Declaration
teidata.xmlName = xsd:NCName
Note

The rules defining an XML name form a part of the XML Specification.

5.28. teidata.xpath

teidata.xpathÂ defines attribute values which contain an XPath expression.

</content>

Note

Any XPath expression using the syntax defined in [[undefined XSLT2]]

6. Constraints

Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:del"> <sch:assertÂ test="@rend">Every strike element must have a @rend attribute of value "strike."</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ uri="http://toscana.newtfire.org" Â prefix="tos"/> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:w[@pos='noun']"> <sch:assertÂ test="@tos:gender">If the anglicism is a noun, you must specify its gender.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:item[not(tei:list)]"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:persName or tei:rs">Every item element must have a child element of persName</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:list[@type='committee']"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:date">Every list element of a committee must have child date element</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:item[ancestor::tei:list[@type='committee']][not(tei:list)]"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:roleName">Every item of a committee list must have a roleName element.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:list[not(ancestor::tei:list)]"> <sch:assertÂ test="@type">Every list element must have @type attribute</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:person/tei:persName[@role='replacement']"> <sch:assertÂ test="following-sibling::tei:date">Every promoted officer must have a date of commencement.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:person/tei:persName[@role='scaduto']"> <sch:assertÂ test="following-sibling::tei:date">Every demoted officer must have a date of relief.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ uri="http://toscana.newtfire.org" Â prefix="tos"/> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:w[not(@pos='prep') and not(@pos='itArt') and not(@pos='conj')]"> <sch:assertÂ test="@tos:orth">With every loanword that is not a preposition, conjunction, or article, you must specifiy whether the orthography complies with English or Italian grammar.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:phr"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:w or tei:phr">In order to use a phr tag, it must contain either a w tag or another phr tag.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:rs"> <sch:assertÂ test="@ref">Every rs element must have a @ref attribute.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@subtype='charity']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='target'] or descendant::tei:orgName[@role='target'] or descendant::tei:rs[@role='target']">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a persName, an orgName, or an rs element with a @role value of "target." </sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@subtype='fondoM']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='target']">Every seg element of @subtype "fondoM" must have persName element with @role value of "target.".</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:num[@type='monetary']">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a num with a @type value of "monetary."</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:num[@value]">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a num with a @value value equivalent to the amount of money being transferred.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@subtype='regale']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='target']">Every seg element of @subtype "regale" must have persName element with @role value of "target.".</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:num[@type='monetary']">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a num with a @type value of "monetary."</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:num[@value]">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a num with a @value value equivalent to the amount of money being transferred.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@subtype='sick']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='target']">Every seg element of @subtypetype "sick" must have persName element with @role value of "target.".</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:num[@type='monetary']">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a num with a @type value of "monetary."</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:num[@value]">Every seg of @type "comp" must have a num with a @value value equivalent to the amount of money being transferred.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@type='comp']"> <sch:assertÂ test="@subtype">Every seg element of @type "comp" must have a @subtype value of either "sick," "charity," "donation," or "fondoM."</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@type='delegation']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='source'] or descendant::tei:rs[@role='source']">Every seg of @type "delegation" must have a persName or rs with a @role value of "source."</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='target']">Every seg of @type "delegation" must have a persName with a @role value of "target."</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@subtype='donation']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='source']">Every seg element of @subtype "donation" must have a descendant persName element with @role value of "source."</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@type='proposal']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='proposer']">Every seg of @type "proposal" must have a persName with a @role value of "proposer."</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='supporter'] or descendant::tei:rs[@role='supporter']">Every seg of @type "proposal" must have a persName or an rs with a @role value of "supporter."</sch:assert> <sch:assertÂ test="@subtype">Every seg of @type "proposal" must have a @subtype value that describes the nature of the proposal.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@type='proposalReject']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='proposer']">Every seg of @type "proposalReject" must have a persName descendant with a @role value of "proposer."</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:seg[@type='proposalWritten']"> <sch:assertÂ test="descendant::tei:persName[@role='proposer']">Every seg of @type "proposalWritten" must have at least one (probably more) persName descendant with a @role value of "proposer."</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:w[@pos='ns' or @pos='npl' or @pos='verb' or @pos='adj']"> <sch:assertÂ test="@tos:accordo">With all noun, verb, and adjective forms, you must determine whether or not the form in question was employed grammatically (with respect to either Italian or English grammar).</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ uri="http://toscana.newtfire.org" Â prefix="tos"/> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:w[not(@pos='prep') and not(@pos='itArt') and not(@pos='conj')]"> <sch:assertÂ test="@tos:modification">With this anglicism, you must speificy whether or not it was modified by the author in any way.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ uri="http://toscana.newtfire.org" Â prefix="tos"/> <sch:ruleÂ context="tei:w[tos:modification='y']"> <sch:assertÂ test="@tos:orth and @tos:add">With all modified anglicisms, you must specify how it was modified.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
